title: "This Is Just To Say" by William Carlos Williams. 1934
text: I have eaten the plums that were in the icebox and which you were probably saving for breakfast Forgive me they were delicious so sweet and so cold

clues.clue: What you do to a meal, or what a hungry person has done to all the snacks.
Past participle of consuming food.
Having consumed food.
These purple fruits are often found in tarts, or sometimes given as a desirable job.
Sweet, juicy fruits with a single pit.
Oval fleshy fruit which is typically purple, reddish-purple, or yellow when ripe, containing a flattened stone.
An old-fashioned chiller, before the era of modern refrigeration.
A non-mechanical refrigerator cooled by ice.
An insulated chest or cabinet cooled by a block of ice.
What you do with money for the future, or what a hero does for the day.
Setting aside for future use or to keep from being lost.
Keeping or storing up (something, especially money) for future use.
The first meal of the day, often featuring toast and coffee.
The morning meal.
A meal eaten in the morning, the first of the day.
What you might ask for after making a mistake, or what a kind heart offers.
To stop feeling angry or resentful toward someone for an offense.
Stop feeling angry or resentful towards (someone) for an offense, flaw, or mistake.
A taste that makes your mouth happy, often paired with 'yummy'.
Having a very pleasant taste or smell.
Highly pleasant to the senses, especially to the taste.
The taste of sugar, or a kind gesture.
Having the pleasant taste characteristic of sugar or honey.
Having the pleasant taste of sugar or honey.
The opposite of hot, often felt in winter or from a frosty gaze.
Having a low temperature.
Of or at a low or relatively low temperature, especially when compared with the human body.
It's likely, but not certain, like predicting tomorrow's weather.
Almost certainly; very likely.
Most likely; with strong probability.
